head.title: The Way We Live Now: 10-22-00; What They Were Thinking

hedline.hl1: The Way We Live Now: 10-22-00; What They Were Thinking

abstract.p: Interview with Helen Dixon, on how she was feeling when mother-in-law, Dorothea Lange, photographed her shortly before giving birth to her second son; photo (M)

block.p: Helen Dixon, Winters, Calif., August 1955 ''I was feeling terrible. It was both the heat and the pregnancy -- just a short while after that I gave birth to my second son, who was 11 pounds. I was wondering if this should be just the normal birth, especially since he was such a large baby, or whether I should have a Caesarean. You have funny feelings in those last few weeks. You just can hardly wait until the birth.

Helen Dixon, Winters, Calif., August 1955 ''I was feeling terrible. It was both the heat and the pregnancy -- just a short while after that I gave birth to my second son, who was 11 pounds. I was wondering if this should be just the normal birth, especially since he was such a large baby, or whether I should have a Caesarean. You have funny feelings in those last few weeks. You just can hardly wait until the birth.

''Dorothea photographed all the time. You got used to it. She was my mother-in-law, and I admired a lot of things she did. I admired her tenacity because she was sick so much of the time. But we were building that house at the time. Dorothea had an awful lot of input. That caused kind of friction, and so I got to the point where I really hated the house. Between pregnancy and all of that, it just got to be so much. I can't say that I love that photograph, simply because I was so miserable at the time.''

Correction: November 5, 2000, Sunday A credit was omitted in The Times Magazine on Oct. 22 for a portrait of Helen Dixon, daughter-in-law of the photographer Dorothea Lange. It should have read, ''Copyright Dorothea Lange Collection, Oakland Museum of California, City of Oakland. Gift of Paul S. Taylor.''
